content.text: Record the \(d\) values in the table
Complete the column headings in the table

A student moves the mass to a distance \(d = 70.0 \text{cm}\) from the pivot. He adjusts the height of the forcemeter until the rule is again horizontal. He records the reading \(F\) on the forcemeter
He repeats the procedure using \(d\) values of 60.0 cm, 50.0 cm, 40.0 cm, 30.0 cm, 20.0 cm and 10.0 cm. The forcemeter readings are shown in Table 1.1
Suggest the graph that you could plot to test this idea. You are not asked to plot the graph
State the properties of the line that would indicate that \(F\) is directly proportional to \(d\)
The student thinks that \(F\) is directly proportional to \(d\)
A spirit level is a piece of equipment that is placed on a surface to check whether the surface is horizontal
Suggest why a spirit level balanced on the rule is not suitable for checking whether the rule is horizontal in this experiment
Describe briefly how you would check that the rule is horizontal in this experiment. You may draw a diagram
[Total: 7]
The IGCSE class is investigating the effect of a load on a metre rule attached to a force
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1
The rule is pivoted near one end at the 10.0cm mark. Near the other end, at the 90.0cm mark, the rule is attached to a forcemeter. A mass is hanging from the rule at a distance \(d\) from the pivot
Record the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer

A student pours approximately \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. She measures the temperature \(\theta\) of the water. She starts a stopclock and records the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at 30s intervals up to time \(t = 150 \text{s}\). The readings are shown in Table 2.1
As you read these words, this experiment is actually being carried out by candidates in many different countries, using identical apparatus
Suggest two differences in the conditions in the various laboratories that might lead to different graphs
[Total: 8]
The IGCSE class is investigating the rate of cooling of water
Fig. 2.1 shows the apparatus
Record the potential difference \(V_{1}\) and the current \(I_{1}\)
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{p}}\) of the combination of the two resistors arranged
parallel using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{p}} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}.\)
Calculate \(4R_{\mathrm{p}}.\)
A student measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across the resistors and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. The readings are shown in Figs. 3.2 and 3.3
The student rearranges the circuit so that the two resistors are connected in series and the voltmeter is connected to measure the potential difference across both resistors
The new potential difference and current readings are \(V_{2} = 1.9 \text{V}\) and \(I_{2} = 0.08 \text{A}\)
Calculate the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{S}}\) of the combination of the two resistors arranged in series using the equation \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = \frac{V_{2}}{I_{2}}.\)

Theory suggests that \(R_{\mathrm{S}} = 4R_{\mathrm{p}}\) if the two resistors have the same value. State whether your results indicate that the resistors have the same value. Justify your answer with reference to the results
statement
justification
Using the circuit described in (b), the student replaces the two series resistors with two lamps
In the space below, draw a circuit diagram of the new circuit using standard symbols
State the function of the variable resistor
Explain why you might want to use a variable resistor in this way
[Total: 10]
A student suggests repeating the experiment described in parts (a) to (c). He calls a variable resistor between the power source and the switch
The IGCSE class is investigating resistor combinations in circuits
The first circuit used is shown in Fig. 3.1
The student has a \(30 \text{cm}\) rule and two rectangular blocks of wood
In the space below, draw a diagram to show clearly how you would arrange the apparatus to measure the diameter of one of the spheres
On Fig. 4.1, show clearly the line of sight that you would use to obtain an accurate volume reading.
Using Fig. 4.1, record the volume \(V\) of water in the measuring cylinder
The student carefully puts 15 of the glass spheres into the measuring cylinder. The new water level reading is \(78 \text{cm}^3\)
Calculate the volume \(V_{1}\) of one sphere

The student then determines the average volume of a glass sphere by a displacement method. She pours some cold water into a measuring cylinder and records the volume \(V\) of the water, as shown in Fig. 4.1
A student is measuring some small glass spheres

On Fig. 5.1, draw a normal at the centre of side \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the point \(\mathbf{E}\) where the normal crosses \(\mathbf{AB}\). Mark a point \(\mathbf{N}\) on the normal \(4.0 \text{cm}\) from \(\mathbf{E}\) and outside the outline of the block

Draw a line \(\mathbf{NF}\) from \(\mathbf{N}\) to the block. This line must be to the right of the normal and at an angle of \(20^{\circ}\) to the normal. Mark the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where the line meets \(\mathbf{AB}\). Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line \(\mathbf{NF}\)
ABCD is a transparent block placed, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet
Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line until it meets \(\mathbf{CD}\). Label this point \(\mathbf{G}\)
Draw the line \(\mathbf{GF}\) and continue it until it meets the normal. Label this point \(\mathbf{H}\)
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line \(\mathbf{FH}\)
Calculate the refractive index \(n\) of the material of the block, using the equation \(n = \frac{b}{a}\)

The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on the line through \(\mathbf{F}\) and \(\mathbf{N}\). She observes the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block so that the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

She places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between her eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\), seen through the block, appear one behind the other. The positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) are marked on Fig. 5.1
Suggest one precaution that you would take in this experiment to obtain readings that are as accurate as possible
[Total: 9]
The IGCSE class is determining the refractive index of the material of a transparent
Fig. 5.1 shows a student's ray-trace sheet
